Define what an involution is in mathematical terms.
Recognize the property of involution, specifically that if p(i) = j, then p(j) = i and every element must either point to itself or to a unique partner.
Determine how to count the number of ways n elements can be paired where each element is either paired with one other element or left as its own pair.

Consider the decomposition of n elements into pairs and single elements: (a) calculate the number of possible ways to have k paired sets (2k elements) and the remaining elements as fixed points (n-2k elements).
Establish the formula that expresses the number of involutions depending on whether elements are paired or not.
Sum the possibilities across all valid k values where k ranges typically from 0 up to the floor(n/2), considering Euler's partition into pairs or singletons.
Derive the total number of involutions for n = 6 using this decomposition strategy.
